name: tf-regulon-analysis
title: TF Regulon Analysis: Gene Regulatory Network Inference with SCENIC
description: Infer transcription factor regulons and gene regulatory networks from single-cell RNA-seq data using SCENIC/pySCENIC. Discover which transcription factors control cell identity, developmental trajectories, and disease states by mapping TF-target relationships with motif-enriched regulatory networks.
content:
üß¨ TF Regulon Analysis: Gene Regulatory Network Inference

Decode Transcription Factor Control of Gene Expression

Transcription factor (TF) regulon analysis reveals the master regulators controlling cellular identity and function. By combining gene co-expression networks with DNA motif analysis, this approach identifies which transcription factors regulate which genes, providing insights into the regulatory logic underlying cell states, development, and disease.

üéØ What is TF Regulon Analysis?

A regulon is a group of genes controlled by the same transcription factor. TF regulon analysis uses computational methods to infer these regulatory relationships from single-cell RNA-seq data, enabling you to:

  • üîç Identify master regulators: Discover which TFs drive specific cell types or states

  • üìä Map regulatory networks: Build gene regulatory networks (GRNs) showing TF-target relationships

  • üß¨ Score TF activity: Quantify transcription factor activity at single-cell resolution

  • üéØ Find direct targets: Distinguish direct TF targets from indirect downstream effects

  • üìà Compare cell states: Understand regulatory changes between conditions, cell types, or time points

üî¨ The SCENIC/pySCENIC Pipeline

This analysis uses SCENIC (Single-Cell rEgulatory Network Inference and Clustering), the gold-standard method for inferring gene regulatory networks from single-cell data.

Three-Step Workflow

Step 1: Gene Regulatory Network Inference

  • Method: GRNBoost2 or GENIE3 algorithms

  • Process: Identify potential TF-target relationships based on gene co-expression patterns

  • Output: Initial co-expression modules linking TFs to candidate target genes

  • Technology: Gradient boosting regression or random forest-based inference

Step 2: Regulon Prediction (cisTarget/RcisTarget)

  • Method: TF motif enrichment analysis using cisTarget databases

  • Process: Prune co-expression modules to retain only genes with enriched TF binding motifs

  • Output: High-confidence regulons containing direct TF targets

  • Databases: Genome-wide motif rankings (Human, Mouse, Fly available)

  • Threshold: Normalized Enrichment Score (NES) > 3.0 for motif significance

Step 3: Cell-Level Regulon Activity (AUCell)

  • Method: AUCell (Area Under the Curve) scoring

  • Process: Calculate regulon activity for each cell based on target gene expression

  • Output: TF activity matrix (cells √ó regulons) for downstream analysis

  • Applications: Cell type identification, trajectory analysis, differential regulation

üìã Input Data Requirements

Expression Matrix

Your single-cell RNA-seq data should be provided as:

  • Format: Gene expression matrix (CSV, TSV, loom, h5ad, or H5)

  • Structure: Genes as rows, cells as columns (or transposed)

  • Values: Raw counts or normalized expression values

  • Filtering: Pre-filtered to remove low-quality cells and genes

  • Size: Typically 500-10,000 cells, 15,000-25,000 genes

Example Format (CSV)

gene,cell_1,cell_2,cell_3,cell_4
GATA1,15,8,45,12
SOX2,120,98,5,110
PAX6,85,92,78,88
MYC,42,38,55,48

Optional Inputs

  • Cell metadata: Cell type labels, experimental conditions, batch information

  • Custom TF list: Focus analysis on specific transcription factors of interest

  • Motif databases: Custom motif rankings for non-standard organisms

üß¨ Reference Genome and Databases

Select the appropriate species for your data:

  • üßë Human (Homo sapiens): GRCh38/hg38 or GRCh37/hg19

    • Motif databases: ~10,000 TF motifs from CIS-BP, JASPAR, SwissRegulon

    • Genome-wide rankings: 20,000+ protein-coding genes

  • üê≠ Mouse (Mus musculus): GRCm39/mm39 or GRCm38/mm10

    • Motif databases: ~9,000 TF motifs adapted for mouse

    • Ortholog mapping: Cross-species regulatory inference

  • ü¶ü Fruit Fly (Drosophila melanogaster): BDGP6/dm6

    • Motif databases: Specialized for Drosophila TFs

    • Developmental regulators: HOX genes, gap genes, pair-rule genes

üìä Analysis Workflow Details

Phase 1: Co-expression Module Discovery

  • Algorithm: GRNBoost2 (Python) or GENIE3 (R) - both use tree-based regression

  • Input: Expression matrix + list of transcription factors

  • Output: Adjacency matrix of TF-gene importance scores

  • Scalability: GRNBoost2 is 10x faster than GENIE3

  • Parameters: Typically analyzes 1,500-2,000 human TFs

Phase 2: Motif-Based Regulon Refinement

  • Database: Pre-computed genome-wide motif rankings

  • Method: Recovery curve analysis for motif enrichment

  • Scoring: Normalized Enrichment Score (NES) calculation

  • Pruning: Retain only targets with significant motif enrichment

  • Annotation: Match motifs to known TF binding specificities

Phase 3: Single-Cell Activity Scoring

  • AUCell algorithm: Rank-based enrichment scoring

  • Per-cell calculation: Evaluate regulon activity in each individual cell

  • Binarization: Optional thresholding to identify "on" vs "off" regulons

  • Output matrix: Cells √ó regulons activity scores

üìä Results and Outputs

Regulon Files

  • üìã Regulon definitions: Lists of TFs and their target genes (JSON, CSV, GMT formats)

  • üéØ Direct targets: High-confidence genes with motif evidence

  • üîç Extended targets: Co-expressed genes without motif support (indirect targets)

  • üìä Motif annotations: DNA binding motifs associated with each regulon

Activity Matrices

  • üßÆ AUCell scores: Continuous regulon activity values per cell

  • üî≤ Binary activity: Thresholded on/off regulon states

  • üìà Normalized scores: Standardized for cross-cell comparisons

  • üíæ File formats: CSV, loom, h5ad (AnnData), or Seurat RDS

Visualizations

  • üó∫Ô∏è UMAP/t-SNE projections: Cells colored by regulon activity

  • üî• Heatmaps: Regulon activity across cell types or conditions

  • üåê Network diagrams: TF-target gene regulatory networks

  • üìä Regulon statistics: Target counts, motif enrichment scores, activity distributions

Quality Metrics

  • üìà Number of regulons: Typically 100-400 high-confidence regulons

  • üéØ Targets per regulon: Average 20-200 direct target genes

  • üîç Motif NES scores: Distribution of enrichment significance

  • üìä Activity correlations: Co-activity patterns between regulons

üî¨ Biological Applications

Cell Type Identification

  • Master regulators: Identify TFs defining specific cell types (e.g., PAX6 for neurons, GATA1 for erythrocytes)

  • Cell type signatures: Use regulon patterns as cell type markers

  • Annotation: Classify unknown cells based on TF activity profiles

Developmental Trajectories

  • Lineage decisions: Track TF activity changes during differentiation

  • Bifurcation points: Identify competing regulons at decision points

  • Temporal dynamics: Map regulatory transitions during development

Disease Mechanisms

  • Cancer regulators: Discover oncogenic TFs driving tumor cell states

  • Disease vs healthy: Compare regulon activity between disease and control

  • Drug targets: Identify druggable TFs controlling disease phenotypes

Perturbation Response

  • Treatment effects: Measure changes in TF regulatory programs after drug treatment

  • Genetic perturbations: Predict effects of TF knockout or overexpression

  • Pathway analysis: Connect TFs to biological pathways and processes

üß™ Experimental Design Best Practices

Data Quality Requirements

  • ‚úì Sequencing depth: Aim for 1,000-5,000 UMIs per cell for robust inference

  • ‚úì Cell numbers: Minimum 500 cells per condition; 2,000-10,000 optimal

  • ‚úì Gene detection: Filter cells with <500 genes and genes detected in <10 cells

  • ‚úì Quality control: Remove doublets, dying cells, and high mitochondrial content

Sample Considerations

  • üî¨ Biological replicates: Include replicates to distinguish biological from technical variation

  • üß¨ Diverse cell types: Include multiple cell states to capture regulatory diversity

  • üìä Batch effects: Control for technical batches during data integration

  • ‚ö° Fresh samples: Use high-viability cells for accurate TF activity measurement

Analysis Parameters

  • üéØ TF list selection: Use curated TF databases (e.g., AnimalTFDB, TFcheckpoint)

  • üìä Expression thresholds: Balance sensitivity vs specificity in co-expression detection

  • üîç Motif databases: Use species-appropriate rankings (human, mouse, or fly)

  • üìà NES cutoff: Standard threshold of NES > 3.0 for motif enrichment

üî¨ Common Research Questions Answered

  • "What TFs define my cell types?" - Identify cell-type-specific master regulators

  • "Which genes does my TF regulate?" - Map direct and indirect target genes

  • "How do TFs change during differentiation?" - Track activity along developmental trajectories

  • "What drives disease cell states?" - Discover dysregulated TFs in pathological conditions

  • "Which TFs co-regulate targets?" - Identify cooperative and antagonistic TF relationships

  • "Can I predict TF perturbation effects?" - Model consequences of TF knockout or activation

üîç Advanced Features

Multi-omics Integration

  • SCENIC+: Integrate scRNA-seq with scATAC-seq for enhancer-gene-TF links

  • Chromatin accessibility: Validate regulons with open chromatin at TF binding sites

  • ChIP-seq validation: Cross-reference with TF binding data

Comparative Analysis

  • Cross-species: Compare regulatory networks across organisms

  • Time-series: Track regulon dynamics over temporal gradients

  • Spatial context: Integrate with spatial transcriptomics

Network Analysis

  • TF cascades: Identify hierarchical regulatory relationships

  • Feed-forward loops: Detect network motifs and regulatory circuits

  • Hub TFs: Find highly connected master regulators

üìö Key Publications

  • Original SCENIC: Aibar et al. (2017) Nature Methods - "SCENIC: single-cell regulatory network inference and clustering"

  • pySCENIC protocol: Van de Sande et al. (2020) Nature Protocols - "A scalable SCENIC workflow for single-cell gene regulatory network analysis"

  • SCENIC+: Bravo Gonz√°lez-Blas et al. (2023) Nature Methods - "SCENIC+: single-cell multiomic inference of enhancers and gene regulatory networks"

jobConfig.name: system_size
jobConfig.description: Select compute resources. TF regulon analysis requires substantial memory and CPU for GRN inference.

options.label: SMALL (8 CPUs, 30GB RAM) - Testing/small datasets (<1000 cells)
MEDIUM (32 CPUs, 120GB RAM) - Standard datasets (1000-5000 cells)
LARGE (64 CPUs, 360GB RAM) - Large datasets (5000-20000 cells, recommended)
XLARGE (96 CPUs, 540GB RAM) - Very large datasets (>20000 cells)

spec.label: Expression Matrix
spec.name: input
spec.description: Single-cell gene expression matrix (CSV, TSV, loom, h5ad, or H5 format). Genes as rows, cells as columns. Pre-filtered for quality.

spec.label: Output Directory
spec.name: outdir
spec.description: Directory where regulon files, activity matrices, network visualizations, and reports will be saved

spec.label: Reference Genome/Species
spec.name: genome
spec.description: Select the species matching your data. This determines which TF motif databases and genome rankings to use.

spec.label: Analysis Method
spec.name: method
spec.description: Gene regulatory network inference method. SCENIC is the gold-standard comprehensive approach.

options.label: SCENIC/pySCENIC (recommended) - Complete GRN inference with motif enrichment
GRNBoost2 only - Fast co-expression network inference without motif pruning
GENIE3 only - Classic co-expression inference (slower than GRNBoost2)

spec.label: Number of Workers/Threads
spec.name: num_workers
spec.description: Number of parallel workers for GRN inference. More workers = faster analysis. Adjust based on system size.

spec.label: Cell Metadata (Optional)
spec.name: metadata
spec.description: Optional CSV file with cell annotations (cell types, conditions, clusters). First column should match cell IDs in expression matrix.

spec.label: Custom TF List (Optional)
spec.name: tf_list
spec.description: Optional text file with transcription factor gene names (one per line) to focus analysis on specific TFs.

spec.label: Motif NES Threshold
spec.name: nes_threshold
spec.description: Normalized Enrichment Score threshold for motif significance. Standard: 3.0. Higher = more stringent.

spec.label: Output Format
spec.name: output_format
spec.description: Preferred format for regulon activity matrices and results.
